content.body: Do some of you folks work on the whatwg project?
this _is_ the whatwg project
Nice.
Now we're moving to the second portion of the HTML5 adoption, which is applying it to our latest out-of-the-box theme.  I have an example @ http://madison.thewikies.com/html5/liferay/
I'm still working on getting the code for our div based columns.  So I know I'm losing everything inside the tables.
o_O
now leif is suggesting ARIA should be used by non-ATs
going directly contrary to the point of ARIA...
well this is dumb
the way i designed the database API, you can't know whether you need to create the tables or not
<-- dumb
Hixie, does [6.11.9 History Traversal] occur on all page loads, even if I type straight into the URL bar?
yes
it is invoked as part of the navigation algorithm
So is popstate fired on all loads?
no
only if there is state to pop
Only if the state to pop is non-null?
I could set the document pending object to null as part of the algorithm.
hold on
jlebar: ok, here now. looking...
jlebar: popstate only fires when an entry in the session history is activated
jlebar: which only occurs if the specified entry is a state object or the first entry for a Document
jlebar: but yes, it fires at least once per Document load
s/but/so/
my statement earlier was incorrect
jlebar: sorry about that!
Hixie, sorry, was afk for a sec.  I'm not totally clear on this: If we load index.html and then go to index.html#foo, do we get one or two popstates?
Once for the initial document load...
one
I see.
you get one for the page load
And if we go back to index.html, we also don't get a popstate, because index.html doesn't have an associated state object.
right
er
well actually...
looks closer
actually yes, you do
you always get a popstate when traversing to the first entry in the history for a Document
is relieved.
Oh...interesting.
not sure that's entirely sane
but it's what it says
Me either.
I've been dispatching popstate whenever we dispatch onload, and also when you go back/forwards to any history entry.
That might be easier for developers to deal with, since it's somewhat consistent.
the original intent was to only dispatch it when hitting an entry that has been pushState()d
i am not sure why we dispatch for the initial page load
I think because you want to know when you go back to it?
i guess, yeah
yeah, that makes sense
So it treats the first history entry for a document as one which was pushState()ed to.
right
that makes sense i guess
maybe?  :)
so the only entries for which you don't fire a popstate per spec are those that were added due to the hash changing
(they get a hashchange)
I see.  That might be a little confusing, because clearstate does clear those.
yeah, that was a recent change
iirc
or at least, that wasn't my original intent
thing is, if we do fire popstate for everything
then authors are going to have to distinguish the state=null-because-first case from the state=null-because-hashchange-will-fire-next case
and that's probably harder than just dealing with those two cases
Hm...  I'm not yet convinced that matters.  Wouldn't they listen to popstate alone in that case?
* rephrased: If they just ignore hashchanges, do they care about differentiating between them?
if they don't distinguish them, then each time the user changes the hash manually, the page is going to reset to the initial state
Hmm
wonders how this would change if we had a setState() function.  Then you *could* associate state with the initial entry.
true
but it's easy enough to remember the state for the initial state
i mean, what they _should_ do is if state is null, or if hashchange is called, just base the state on the url
i guess we could call popstate always
do any other UAs implement this yet?
That's how I've been imagining it working.  That way you can bookmark the page and it'll do the right thing.
I'm not aware of any other UAs working on this.
try e-mailing the list and seeing what others think of it
Will do.
if it's not too late for shipped implementations, i can change it to just always fire popstate
my contribution to the web: events firing all the damn time. :-/
Okay.  I'll try and send out an e-mail soon.  I have a few other things in there, but they don't require the Author to parse the spec for me.  :)
i guess nothing i've done with events is as bad as mutation events, still
jlebar: k :-)
Thanks, Hixie.
np
wonders why adding features to the web platform feels like a continuous exercise in damage mitigation
it's like trying to build a sandcastle under a waterfall
lol.  And you have four large, powerful groups of people all telling you that they don't like the shape of your crenelations.
fan more than four
far, even
there's the IETF people, the accessibility people, microsoft, google, apple, mozilla, opera, the TAG, the RDFa people...
Yeah.  I'm only just beginning to get into this, but...I don't envy that.
eh, the sad thing is i enjoy it
i'm a sucker i guess :-P
:)  I need to go catch my train now.  Thanks again!
later!
shepazu: xhr was part of html5
it was the first spec to be spun off
Hello all.
anyone know how focus and blur events work on Window objects?
Hixie: I think they fire based on the window gaining or losing focus
more detail than that, I don't know
i guess i'll look into it on wednesday
bed now
nn
Night, Hixie.

focus is when a particular element is active, like when a link is selected and has that little dotted outline in firefox, or when your mouse is pressed inside an input element and the text cursor is flashing, when you "enter" that element, that is focus.
Blur is the opposite and occurs only when you leave a particular element.
oh geez, you asked about window objects, not elements.
If you're talking about the window that shows you the body of the page, then it works the same as the elements.
when the window is active and when you're on the tab of that particular page, it's active.
you have to actively leave the tab by switching to another one or minimizing the window to trigger blur.
Hixie: XHR came to W3C long before HTML5 did... with regards to the Rec track, it's not a "spin-off" in that sense
not that long
less than a year
and it did came out of what became known as HTML5 later
it's even part of the acknowledgments
thinks the maturity level req for normative references is entirely unhelpful
XMLHttpRequest is not moving that fast at the moment
mostly awaiting more impl feedback
shepazu: it was spun off before WHATWG Web Apps 1.0 was officially adopted as W3C HTML5
hsivonen: it somewhat makes sense to me that, if you normatively depend on an unstable spec, it's dubious to declare yourself frozen
hsivonen: but since Web technology has turned out to be a web of specs and not a hierarchy, it does seem like it could impede progress
othermaciej: implementations aren't going to stabilize at a point where they are only implementing RECs
hsivonen: that tends to undermine the idea of RECs at all
othermaciej: instead, any particular piece of the platform may advance ahead of components that rely on the service the piece provides
I am not sure what the right process is for Web standards
othermaciej: I'm not a believer in RECs, either.
implementations move too fast
for the traditional standards process
but never stabilizing anything also seems like a bad idea
it makes sense to stabilize stuff, but making spec division as granular as actual stability would be prohibitively bureaucratic
we'd have on W3C doc per DOM method
s/on/one/
even the WHATWG section-level stability isn't quite granular enough to annotate real implementation stability
I rather like the analogy Hixie made with U.S. Code
probably still more practical than doing it per-method
shepazu, please...
(re latest email)
annevk2: what? you raised a totally pedantic point that wasn't even correct, nor was it pertinent to the subject at hand... you expected a serious reply?
dream on
shepazu: what was annevk2's pedantic point?
the same as hixie's, naturally... to which I'd already replied in this channel
hmm
the WHATWG twitter account is no longer updated?
probably a problem with twitter I suppose :/
shepazu: the original contents of the W3C XHR spec were once in "Web Apps 1.0", which at the time was known unofficially as HTML5 and now is known officially as HTML5
shepazu: I'm not sure what your goal is in casting doubt on that record

othermaciej: "casting doubt on that record"? I laid it out explicitly... you might as well ask what anne's point was in claiming XHR originated with the HTML5 spec... it's totally irrelevant to the explanation I was making for Shelley about what the relationship of specs on the Rec-track are
I was just making a small nit about your statement being the editor of XMLHttpRequest and all
why is it always a political debate when someone gets off the party line?
shepazu: the part of your email he quoted said "XmlHttpRequest (XHR) spec, which was never part of HTML5"
I think he just gave a simple factual correction, from his perspective
I don't believe anyone but you is making it political
pft.
it was a side point which I don't think invalidates the rest of your comments
void save(); // push state on state stack
void restore(); // pop state stack and restore state
why aren't these called push and pop?
save and restore makes it sound like there can be only one state
wtf??? http://www.fujinonbinos.com/
(view source)
shepazu: awesomeness
code as art?
my eyes hurt
the Poseidon Series, appropriately, goes very deep

<META NAME="generator" CONTENT="Web Studio, Version 4.0 for Windows">

so it doesn't really have a concept of DOM
too bad

on the codec topic: did VLC regress or remove Dirac support?
so Firefox does support ISO88599 unlike IE but like Chromium and Opera
but it does not support ISO-8859_9 unlike IE, Chromium and Opera
how about ISO-8859-9? :>
including the question mark? </smart-ass>
wouldnt be a question then, would it? :P
you win :)
What are the non-aria uses of role now that xhtml2 is going away?
Dashiva: none
guesses Hixie is sleeping
Then what's up with the role vs aria-role thread?
I don't think everyone is in agreement that role="" is just for WAI-ARIA
Dashiva: role is an inconsistent name when everything else in ARIA has the aria-* prefix
Dashiva: it sucks, but it's too late. not too serious to worry about, IMO.
annevk5: who disagrees except the XHTML2 WG?
The people who brought it up I assume
But nobody knows here what other uses are being considered?
I don't fully understand what they want

I don't understand that thread at all. Jim stated in his e-mail about it that "ARIA roles are not the *only* use of the role attribute", and regardless of whether that's true or not, it refutes his own argument for making it aria specific
non-ARIA uses of role are handled by class :-)
<element element-role="div">
I think he wants aria-role and role so that you can have <input type=checkbox aria-role=radio role=url>
http://www.w3.org/mid/op.uyupstgqidj3kv⊙sl
back to ABNF?
or XML BNF or whatever it is
it's XML 1.0 EBNF
so the new rule is not matching the EBNF is ignoring the entire PI?
yeah
plus duplicate pseudo-attribute and �
XML infoset? :/
the wg doesn't like having it defined in terms of the dom, because not all impl use a dom...
but they were fine with infoset
hmm, it also doesn't define impl requirements anymore it seems
e.g. section 5 seems more like a description for authors than implementors
http://simon.html5.org/specs/xml-stylesheet5 is nicer :)
is somewhat positively surprised with http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/http-state/current/msg00191.html

Lachy: Given that it is to distinguish him from the more famous Robert Smith I guess he got his name changed
Kinda like Mike(TM)Smith but moreso

Although that may be unduly cynical, it is worth noting that it is by someone who thought that doing a study on disease propogation using zombies was a good idea and who appended a question mark to their name
